Платформа Молодых Дизайнеров (YDP)

  1. Главная
  2. О нас

Garment industry in Kyrgyzstan

Development of textile and garment industry in Kyrgyzstan dates back to the Soviet era, especially, to the periods during and after the World War II.

Wool, cotton and leather clothes manufactured in the Kyrgyz Republic were valued for their high quality all across the Soviet Union.

After the fall of the USSR in 1991, during the next few years most of the textile producing and garment manufacturing factories were forced to stop production/dissolve due to major economic downturn caused by disruption of logistic chains between newly emerged independent countries leading to shortage of raw materials, emigration of technical personnel, hyperinflation, privatization, etc.

Opening of borders with China led to gradual growth of trade and service industry. Individual traders began to import cheap Chinese goods (mainly clothes), re-export them to certain CIS countries (Kazakhstan and Russia being the major ones), or trade themselves in the bazaars of the above-mentioned countries. Since 2002, the introduction of customs duties and VAT on the territory of some CIS countries has severely limited the re-export of Chinese garments and textiles, which prompted entrepreneurs to start and develop clothing manufacturing in Kyrgyzstan. In a short period, garments manufactured in Kyrgyzstan have become in demand in almost all bazaars in Russia, Kazakhstan and other countries. Due to the high demand, large and small production workshops began to open providing new job opportunities for local people. That is how the garment manufacturing industry in Kyrgyzstan began to grow. Today, according to official statistics, it is one of the locomotives of the Kyrgyz economy, making up approximately 3% of the country’s GDP officially. But real figures are definitely far higher given the fact that the share of the shadow economy in the country is quite high, especially in this industry. More than 160 thousand people are employed in the garment manufacturing industry, both domestically and abroad.

Our project

Over the past 3 years, working with representatives of both the garment industry and educational institutions that train future technologists and designers, as Egemendik PA, we’ve developed a very clear understanding of the problem described above.

On this basis, we came up with a proposal to address this problem, albeit on a small scale, by creating a medium/platform for young talents in garment design to: • improve their skills, unleash their talents and creative potential; • encourage collaboration between emerging designers and clothing manufacturers; • offer employment opportunities.

The far-reaching goal of this project, which we call the Young Designers Platform (shortly YDP), is to promote the development of the garment industry in the country as a whole.

As part of the project, we intend to hold a 5-month-long training program for young designers and a design contest at the end of trainings. The project will consist of the following parts: • Preparation of an action plan, development of YDP website; • Announcement of the project through the website and other media channels and acceptance of applications (end of September - end of October); • Selection of program participants (at least 15 undergraduate students in their junior and senior years) and orientation meeting (November); • Conducting courses on industrial software products on graphic design, clothing modeling and 3D fashion design to develop the technical skills of participants (December-March); • Conducting visits to exemplary garment factories (December-March); • Master classes, motivational seminars and trainings from leading designers in Kyrgyzstan (December-March); • Announcement of the theme of the contest for the final display of the participants’ collections; • Financial support for participants to create their collections; • Final display of the participants’ collections, ceremony of awarding the winners and handing of certificates.
